title: Two conducting spheres set - rank E fields at RSTU

content.description: Two concentric spherical conducting shells and four labeled points <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi> </math>, <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math>, and <math alttext="U" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi></math> are shown in the figure. The outer shell has a net charge of <math alttext="negative 20 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math>. The inner shell has a net charge of <math alttext="positive 10 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math>.
content.question: The magnitudes of the electric fields at points <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math>, <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math>, and <math alttext="U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi></math> are <math alttext="E sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="E sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="E sub U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively. Which of the following correctly compares the magnitudes of the electric fields?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub S is greater than E sub T, which is greater than open parenthesis, E sub R equals E sub U, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="open parenthesis, E sub S equals E sub T, close parenthesis, is greater than E sub U, which is greater than E sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mpadded><mpadded><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></mpadded></mpadded></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="open parenthesis, E sub S equals E sub T, close parenthesis, is greater than, open parenthesis, E sub R equals E sub U, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub T is greater than E sub S, which is greater than E sub R, which is greater than E sub U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub S is greater than E sub T, which is greater than open parenthesis, E sub R equals E sub U, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>T</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
